journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Transport properties of polyester composite reinforced with treated sisal fibers

contrib-group.aff: 1National Institute of Technology Calicut, NITC P O, Calicut, India.
2Department of Chemical Engineering, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Dhahran, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
3Laboratoire de Physique, Energétique Appliquée (LPEA), Université El-Hadj-Lakhdar Batna, 1 rue Chahid Boukhlouf Mohamed El-Hadi, Batna, Algeria.
4Université Paris-Est Créteil, CERTES, 61 Av. du Général de Gaulle, Créteil Cedex, France.
5School of Chemical Sciences, Mahatma Gandhi University, Priyadarshini Hills P O, Kottayam, Kerala, India.

author-notes.corresp: B. Agoudjil, Université El-Hadj-Lakhdar Batna, 1 rue Chahid Boukhlouf Mohamed El-Hadi, 05000 Batna, Algeria Email: agoudjil@u-pec.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Thermal conductivity, diffusivity, relative permittivity, specific heat, and tensile properties of sisal/polyester composites were investigated as a function of fiber volume fraction and fiber surface modification. The composites were prepared by resin transfer molding (RTM) technique. Sisal fibers were subjected to various chemical and physical modifications such as mercerization, heating at 100°C, permanganate treatment, benzoylation, and silanization to improve the interfacial bonding with matrix. All treatments used in this study improved the relative permittivity, tensile strength, Young’s modulus, and reduced the elongation at break. The use of NaOH and silane treatments decreased the thermal conductivity. Beside these, a comparison between dielectric, mechanical, and thermal behaviors of the composites was reported in this paper. A linear dependence of the relative variation of dielectric permittivity, Young’s modulus, and thermal conductivity was also shown for untreated systems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years the study of natural fiber reinforced composites has stimulated immense interest in the area of packaging, building, and automotive industry. The hike in the cost of petroleum products and the potentiality of natural fibers as reinforcement changed the interest of scientists and technologists to study the usage of these fibers as reinforcement in polymer matrix. Several investigators prepared and evaluated the properties of composites based on jute, sisal, hemp, pineapple, oil palm, coir, banana, etc. in different polymer matrices.1–7

Among the different types of properties of composites, (i) thermophysical properties such as effective thermal conductivity and effective thermal diffusivity, (ii) mechanical properties such as tensile strength and Young’s modulus, (iii) dielectric properties such as relative permittivity are of great importance for scientists and engineers for specific purpose of a particular composite.3,6–14 Due to the great number of applications it is essential to study the physical properties of composites. The physical properties of composites are strongly influenced by fiber length,15,16 fiber loading,3,17,18 fiber orientation,8 and fiber/matrix interfacial parameters.11,18–21

Among natural fibers, sisal fiber is one of the widely used plant fibers. It is obtained from the leaves of the Agave sisalana plant, which is largely available in tropical zone countries.15,20 The main drawback of using the natural fibers in polymers is the poor compatibility between them.6 In addition, the hydrophilic character of the natural fibers leads to high moisture absorption causing dimensional changes in the fibers.22 These problems can be overcome by treating the fibers with suitable thermal or chemical treatments to improve fiber-matrix interfacial bonding to reduce water absorption.21,23–25 Most previous studies were focused on the fiber-surface treatment methods and the resultant effects on physical and mechanical properties of composites. Several authors have studied the surface morphology, mechanical and degradation properties of the treated fibers. A special review of sisal fiber treatment for improving mechanical properties of composites has been presented by Li et al.20

The effects of fiber volume fraction, fiber length, and fiber orientation angle on the thermal conductivity of short carbon fiber reinforced polymer composites was studied by Fu and Mai.8 It was found that the thermal conductivity of composite increases almost linearly with fiber content. When fiber thermal conductivity is high, the thermal conductivity of composite increases significantly and when mean fiber length is increased, the mean fiber orientation angle is decreased. Sangthong et al.15 analyzed the effect of fiber length on tensile properties of sisal/polyester composites and concluded that both tensile strength and modulus increased with increase in fiber length. Another interesting work done by Idicula et al.11 showed that chemical treatment of fiber reduces thermal contact resistance between fibers and matrix.

Among the different fabrication methods, RTM is gaining more attention for the preparation of high performance thermoset composites. Many studies were reported in the area of flow front visualization, modeling of void formation, numerical simulations of curing, etc. using synthetic and natural fibers.26–28 Very limited studies were reported on the characterization of the randomly oriented short natural fiber reinforced thermoset composites prepared using RTM.29–31

In this article, we are focusing on the thermal conductivity, thermal diffusivity, specific heat, relative permittivity, and mechanical properties of sisal/polyester composites as a function of fiber content and fiber surface modification. Very low cost treatments were used for the fiber surface modification. These treatments are mercerization, benzoylation, silane, heat, and permanganate. In addition, we compared the relative permittivity εr, the Young’s modulus E, and the thermal conductivity k of composites in order to check the existence of some correlations between these properties.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
Raw sisal fibers were purchased from Sheeba fibers and handicrafts, Poovancode, Tamil Nadu, India. Isophthalic polyester resin, cobaltnapthenate (accelerator) and methyl ethyl ketone peroxide (curing agent) used in this study were of commercial grade and was provided by Makson enterprises, Kottayam, Kerala, India. The properties of sisal fiber and polyester resin used are given in Table 1. Chemicals used for fiber surface modification such as sodium hydroxide, benzoylchloride, and potassium permanganate were also of commercial grade and was purchased from the local sources. Vinyl tris (2 ethoxymethoxy) silane coupling agent used was kindly supplied by Lab agencies, Bangalore, India. Table 1.
Properties of sisal fiber and isophthalic polyester resin
Sisal fiber Isophthalic polyester resin
Diameter (µm) 100–300 Appearance Pale yellow color
Length (mm) 30 Viscosity (cps) 650
Density (g/cm3) 1.45 Density (g/cm3) 1.19
Cellulose (%) 65–78 Elongation at break (%) 4 ± 0.1
Hemicellulose (%) 10–14 Tensile strength (MPa) 41 ± 2.0
Pectin (%) 10 Young’s modulus (MPa) 968 ± 5.0
Lignin (%) 9.90 Flexural strength (MPa) 61 ± 2.26
Waxes (%) 2 Flexural modulus (MPa) 2461 ± 2.22
Elongation at break (%) 4–9
Tensile strength (MPa) 365 ± 5.2
Young’s modulus (MPa) 12,250 ± 6.8

sec.title: Thermal treatment (RH)
sec.p: Chopped sisal fibers were subjected to heat at 100°C for 4 h in an air-circulating oven continuously.

sec.title: Permanganate treatment (RP)
sec.p: Sisal fibers were soaked in 0.02% concentrated KMnO4/acetone for 3 min. Fibers were then taken out, washed many times with distilled water and kept in an air oven at 70°C until it becomes dried.

sec.title: NaOH treatment (RN)
sec.p: Chopped sisal fibers were fully immersed in 5% of NaOH solution for 30 min. The fibers were then washed with dilute hydrochloric acid to remove any traces of alkali. Washing was continued till all the fibers were free from alkali. The fibers were kept in an air oven at 70°C until it becomes dried.

sec.title: Silane treatment (RS)
sec.p: Vinyl tris(2-ethoxymethoxy) silane (0.6%) was mixed well with an ethanol/water mixture in the ratio 6:4, and allowed to stand for 1 h. The pH of the solution was maintained at a value of four to bring about the complete hydrolysis of the silane by the addition of acetic acid. Neatly separated cellulose fibers were dipped in the above solution and were allowed to remain as such for 90 min. The ethanol–water mixture was drained out and the fibers were kept in an air oven at 70°C until it becomes dried.

sec.title: Benzoylation (RB)
sec.p: Sisal fibers were soaked in NaOH solution and agitated well with 50 mL of benzoylchloride. The mixture was kept for 15 min, filtered and washed thoroughly with water. Subsequently, the fibers were soaked in ethanol for 1 h to remove the unreacted benzoylchloride, finally washed with water and dried in an air oven at 70°C until it becomes dried.

sec.title: Composites preparation
sec.p:
Fabrication was done using RTM technique. The mold was polished and mold-releasing agents were applied. The treated and untreated fibers (fiber length 30 mm) were arranged in the mold in the form of mat, clamped tightly, and vacuum is applied. Isophthalic polyester resin was mixed with 1 wt% cobaltnapthenate (accelerator) and 1 wt% methyl ethyl ketone peroxide (curing agent). This resin mixture was allowed to pass through the closed mold under a pressure of 1 N/m2. Vacuum was applied simultaneously at vent position in the mold. The curing was done for 12 h. After demolding from the mold, the composites were post-cured at 80°C for 4 h. Composite sheets were prepared by varying fiber loading (≈20, 30, and 40 vol%), which corresponds to the composites R20, R30, and R40 respectively. For the treated fiber-reinforced composites, the samples have been coded as RN40, RH40, RB40, RP40, and RS40: where ‘R’ represents resin transfer molding, ‘N’ mercerization, ‘H’ heat treatment, ‘B’ benzoylation, ‘P’ permanganate treatment, ‘S’ silane treatment, and ‘40’ for the fiber content. Details of the composition of composites prepared in this study are given in Table 2. Table 2.
Properties of the composites
Samples Sample number Fiber treatment Fiber loading (Vol%) ρ (kg/m3)
Neat polyester 1 – 0 1190 ± 23
R20 2 – 20 1200 ± 18
R30 3 – 30 1190 ± 17
R40 4 – 40 1180 ± 15
RH40 5 Thermal 40 1180 ± 28
RP40 6 Permanganate 40 1290 ± 27
RN40 7 NaOH 40 1230 ± 17
RS40 8 Silane 40 1150 ± 15
RB40 9 Benzoylation 40 1300 ± 19

sec.title: Thermophysical measurements
sec.p: All thermophysical experiments were performed using samples of dimensions 44 × 44 × (2.3–3.6) mm3. The thermal conductivity and diffusivity of composites were determined simultaneously using a periodic method.32,33 These thermophysical parameters were obtained at room temperature with their corresponding statistical confidence bounds.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) studies were conducted using a Zeiss FESEM supra 25 device to analyze the untreated and treated sisal fiber surfaces.

sec.title: Mechanical testing
sec.p: Tensile properties were determined according to ASTM D638-76 standard. The measurements were done using a universal testing machine (Model TNE 500, Blue star, India) at a crosshead speed of 5 mm/min at room temperature. Five samples were tested in each experiment and the average value is reported.

sec.title: Dielectric permittivity measurement
sec.p: The permittivity measurements were performed at room temperature on the samples by fixing between two copper plates of thickness t = 9 mm.34 In that case, samples constitute a capacitor with an electrical capacitance noted C. The effective capacitance of samples was measured with a RCL meter using four electrodes in order to reduce the effect of the impedance of connectors and cables. The AC voltage applied on samples was fixed to 2 V RMS and the measurements of the electrical capacitance were performed using a large frequency range (50 Hz < f < 106 Hz) without using guarded electrodes. A correction of experimental values was performed in order to take into account the presence of edge effects according to the procedure described in a previous paper.35 Considering the geometry of samples used for dielectric measurements, the maximum correction obtained is about 5%. Then relative dielectric permittivity εr is computed as follows: (1) where ε0 = 8.85 × 10−12 F/m is the vacuum dielectric permittivity, C is the corrected measured capacitance, e is the sample thickness, and D2 the area of electrodes. Relative dielectric permittivity measurements have shown a negligible dependence of permittivity in the whole frequency range of measurements. Besides, there is no significant evolution of the shape of εr(f) curves upon filler loading. In the case where the shape of εr(f) curves is conserved whatever the filler loading, all curves at different fibers concentration must superimpose with the curve of the polyester matrix. This allows determining the increase or decrease in dielectric permittivity with respect to the polyester matrix. For each sample, five successive experiments were performed and an average value reported. Uncertainties were computed considering the standard deviation of experimental values of dielectric permittivity and uncertainties of the measurement device and on samples dimensions.

sec.title: Effect of fiber content
sec.p:
Table 3 presents the thermal conductivity, diffusivity, specific heat, and relative permittivity of untreated and various treated sisal/polyester composites. It is clear that the addition of untreated sisal into polyester resin causes an increase of (i) 13% in the thermal conductivity, (ii) 30% in the thermal diffusivity and (iii) 65% in the relative permittivity and a decrease of 14% in specific heat. Also as the fiber content increases the variation of the density is not significant. Figure 1 represents the relative permittivity and the thermal conductivity of composites vs. fiber volume concentration of untreated sisal/polyester composites. As shown in Figure 1, an increase of thermal conductivity and relative permittivity is observed with increase in fiber volume fraction. An increase of thermal conductivity was previously observed in sisal fiber low-density polyethylene composites by Kalaprasad et al.10 These authors explained this phenomenon by the fact that the fibers form conductive chains in the matrix and, as the fiber content increases, the chance of formation of conductive fiber chains also increases.10 Moreover, the thermal conductivity value of sisal fiber is higher than the polyester resin which also contributes for this increment. The increase in dielectric permittivity is a classical result due on one hand to the presence of absorbed water, dipoles, and ions on natural fibers and on the other hand to increased space charge polarization due to the presence of fiber/matrix interfaces.10 From Figure 1, it can also be seen that the thermal conductivity behavior of the composites under study is quite similar to their dielectric behavior. Thus, a comparison between these behaviors seems interesting. Figure 1.
Relative permittivity and thermal conductivity of composites vs. fiber volume concentration. Table 3.
Measured values of thermal conductivity, thermal diffusivity, and relative permittivity of composites
Samples Sample number k (W/mK) a (×10−7 m2/s) Cp (J/kg/K) εr
Neat polyester 1 0.181 ± 0.003 1.08 ± 0.09 1408 ± 23 3.60 ± 0.04
R20 2 0.198 ± 0.004 1.34 ± 0.06 1231 ± 18 5.27 ± 0.04
R30 3 0.203 ± 0.003 1.40 ± 0.05 1218 ± 17 5.67 ± 0.04
R40 4 0.205 ± 0.003 1.41 ± 0.04 1232 ± 15 5.95 ± 0.07
RH40 5 0.201 ± 0.003 1.42 ± 0.05 1199 ± 28 6.31 ± 0.06
RP40 6 0.214 ± 0.007 1.36 ± 0.12 1219 ± 27 7.38 ± 0.03
RN40 7 0.151 ± 0.003 1.21 ± 0.07 1014 ± 17 9.22 ± 0.04
RS40 8 0.176 ± 0.003 1.27 ± 0.03 1205 ± 15 5.46 ± 0.04
RB40 9 0.234 ± 0.003 1.45 ± 0.04 1241 ± 19 6.12 ± 0.03

Figure 2 shows the variation in tensile strength and the Young’s modulus of the composites as a function of fiber volume fraction. It should be noted that as fiber content increases tensile strength and Young’s modulus of the composite increases (Table 4). When the fiber loading is 40 vol%, the tensile strength, Young’s modulus, and elongation at break are found to be increased by 63%, 127%, and 50%, respectively, as compared to values of neat polyester. The same trend was also reported by some authors such as in hemp fiber reinforced polyester composite,23 in banana/sisal/polyester,3 in banana/glass hybrid phenol formaldehyde,36 in kenaf reinforced poly-l-lactic acid (PLLA)37 and in phenol formaldehyde composites reinforced with banana fibers.17 According to the authors of Idicula et al.,3 the increase in tensile strength is due to the reinforcing action of the fibers. Beside this, the addition of cellulose fibers makes the matrix ductile. The brittle nature of polyester resin decreases with the addition of sisal fibers and therefore elongation at break value increases with fiber loading. This increase in the elongation at break with the fiber loading is attributed by the higher elongation of natural fiber compared to polyester. Figure 2.
Young’s modulus and tensile strength of composites vs. fiber volume concentration. Table 4.
Mechanical properties of the composites
Samples Sample number Tensile strength (MPa) Young’s modulus (MPa) Elongation at break (%)
Neat polyester 1 41 ± 2 968 ± 5 4 ± 0.1
R20 2 50 ± 1 1750 ± 5 5 ± 0.2
R30 3 57 ± 1 1956 ± 3 7 ± 0.2
R40 4 67 ± 1 2196 ± 6 6 ± 0.1
RH40 5 74 ± 2.1 2559 ± 19 3 ± 0.2
RP40 6 72 ± 1.5 2697 ± 14 2.4 ± 0.1
RN40 7 79 ± 1.8 3002 ± 45 3 ± 0.2
RS40 8 76 ± 2.2 2444 ± 45 3.5 ± 0.3
RB40 9 70 ± 1.8 2431 ± 48 3.2 ± 0.3

To conclude, the fiber incorporation increases the thermal conductivity, diffusivity, relative permittivity, tensile strength, Young’s modulus, elongation at break, and decreases the specific heat. Thermal, dielectric, and mechanical behaviors of the composites under study are quite similar and thus a correlation may exist between these behaviors.

sec.title: Effect of fiber surface modifications
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the effect of different treatments on thermal, mechanical and dielectric properties of the composites under study. It is clear that most of the fiber surface treatments improved the relative permittivity, tensile strength, and Young’s modulus of sisal/polyester composites, but to varying degrees. The opposite effect is noted for the elongation at break (Table 4). For the thermal conductivity, there is only a marginal increase when using permanganate and benzoylation treatments. The use of NaOH and silane treatments decreases the thermal conductivity, whereas thermal treatment does not induce any significant variation in thermo-physical properties of the composites. Figure 3.
Effect of different treatments on thermal, mechanical, and dielectric properties of composites.

sec.title: Thermal treatment (RH)
sec.p: For the thermal treated fiber reinforced composites, the increase in εr, E, and tensile strength values is assumed to be due to the removal of moisture from fibers. For macromolecules water acts like a plasticizer, thus a drying process like a thermal treatment induces a decrease in the ductility of sisal fibers and an increase in their modulus. Moreover it has been observed that a thermal treatment of 4 h at 150°C of fibers induces an increase of strength and modulus due to an increased crystallinity of cellulose.18 This treatment decreased the elongation at break of the composites. Among fiber treatments tested in this study, thermal treatment induces a less important variation in the thermal, dielectric, and mechanical properties. Thus, it seems that this treatment does not bring strong modifications of the composition, surface, and structure of fibers.

sec.title: NaOH treatment (RN)
sec.p:
Lignin, hemicellulose, and amorphous components, maintain the link between cellulose units, which are partly crystallized. NaOH reacts with hydroxyls groups of the cementing material hemicellulose, inducing its dissolution. The removal of hemicellulose, lignin, and waxes leads to the destruction of the cellular structure, thereby the fibers split into filaments.38 The division of cellulose fibers is called fibrillation.20 Figure 4(a) and (d) show that the lumps of the cementing materials in untreated fiber were removed by the NaOH treatment. Fibrillation induces an increase in the roughness of fiber and the surface area available for contact with the matrix. Hence, increase in the fiber aspect ratio caused by reduced fiber diameter and generation of rough surface topography offer better fiber/matrix interface adhesion leading to an increase in mechanical properties apart from elongation at break. NaOH treatment leads to an irreversible mercerization effect, which increases the amount of amorphous cellulose at the expense of crystalline cellulose.39 Figure 4.
SEM of sisal fiber after treatment: (a) untreated; (b) benzoylation; (c) permanganate treated; (d) NaOH treated; (e) silane treated.

Fiber fibrillation and amorphization of cellulose might be responsible for the decrease of thermal conductivity. If thermal conduction is improved by the conductive chains formed by fibers, fiber fibrillation corresponding to decohesion of the fibers induces a lowering of the thermal conduction. Moreover, thermal conductivity of a given organic material is higher when chains are organized and form crystalline structures than in the case of an amorphous phase.10 Otherwise, this treatment induced the most important increase of dielectric permittivity. This observation could be in agreement with the fact that mobility of dipoles is higher in defibrillated fibers and in amorphous regions than in crystalline structures. Moreover, the NaOH treatment leads to an O–Na+ ionic bond replacing −OH function group of hemicellulose as proposed in Sreekumar et al.,38 this is also resulting in a higher value of ε′. The lower impact resistance of these composites38 seems to confirm this hypothesis of degradation of fibers by fibrillation.

sec.title: Benzoylation (RB)
sec.p: The possible reaction mechanism during the benzoylation of sisal fibers is given in Sreekumar et al.38 In the benzoylation treatment, the use of sodium hydroxide removes the alkali-soluble fractions like waxy layer, lignin, etc. from fibers. Benzoyl groups linked to the fibers can form chemical links with the matrix. A comparison of the SEM observations on untreated fibers (Figure 4(a)) and benzoylated fibers (Figure 4(b)) indicates that benzoylation causes small voids and rougher surface of fibers, which helps the penetration of the resin into the fiber. This might explain the slight increase of thermal conductivity due to a lower thermal contact resistance between fibers and matrix.

sec.title: Permanganate treatment (RP)
sec.p: For permanganate-treated fibers, grafting of Mn3+ ion to the fiber surface increases the fiber/matrix adhesion. Grafting of ions might be responsible for the significant increase in dielectric permittivity observed for this treatment. Figure 4(c) shows that permanganate treatment also causes an increase in the roughness of the fiber. According to the authors of Joseph et al.,21 the mechanism for improvement of the interfacial properties by permanganate treatment is that the permanganate roughens the fiber surface and produces mechanical interlocks with the matrix. Hence, the interfacial bonding between permanganate-treated sisal fiber and matrix is improved. However, this interfacial bonding does not seem to reduce strongly thermal contact resistance between fibers and matrix as the increase of thermal conductivity observed is lower than the one observed after benzoylation of fibers. Thus, this treatment seems to be less efficient in improving heat transport ability than benzoylation.

sec.title: Silane treatment (RS)
sec.p: In the case of silane treatment, traces of moisture in the fiber hydrolyze the silanes to form silanol. The hydrolyzed silanol forms strong covalent bonds or hydrogen bonds with −OH group of cellulose. The individual coupling agent molecules attached to cellulose forms a continuous link. The long hydrophobic polymer chain polymerized silane can adhere to the matrix mainly because of van der Waals forces. As a result, silane-coupling agents form a bridge at the interface and causes good fiber/matrix adhesion. Coupling agents penetrate the cell wall trough surface pores and deposit in the interfibrillar region. The introduction of long chain structures onto the sisal fiber changes its hydrophilic characteristics, thus water absorption of composites is reduced. The presence of these long chains at the fiber/matrix interface corresponds to the lowest density of all composites. The presence of free volume at the interface is suspected. In this case the thermal contact resistance of the interface is increased and may be linked with the lowering of the thermal conductivity of these samples. In a previous study it was shown that a silane treatment does not increase thermal conductivity of banana fibers/PP composites. 40

sec.title: Summary of fiber treatments effects
sec.p: From Figure 3, it is noted that all treatments resulted in the lowering of elongation at break of the composites. This decrease indicates that the composites become brittle with treatments. During mechanical tests on composites, a better adhesion at the fibers/matrix interface induces a transfer of stresses to the fibers. It usually results in an increase of Young’s modulus, tensile strength, and a decrease of elongation at break.

In the case of natural fibers, it is more complex to understand the evolution of mechanical properties. Indeed the treatments can modify the composition and the structure of the fibers. Thus, the lowering of the elongation at break obtained for all the treatments may have different origins. In the thermal treatment case, the fibers may have become more brittle. At the same time the fiber/matrix adhesion is higher because of the disappearance of water molecules at the interface. For chemical treatments, they can induce the dissolution of cementing materials (lignin, hemicellulose) or waxes and/or the degradation of cellulosic fibers. Concerning fibers/matrix interfaces different events promote adhesion. The chemical degradation of fibers increases their roughness promoting mechanical anchorage of the polymeric matrix. Some chemical treatments modify the hydrophobicity of fibers promoting its reinforcing effect in polymer matrix. The formation of long hydrophobic polymer chain by coupling agents like silane treatment increases interfacial adhesion in the composites.

As a result, all treatments used in this study increases the tensile strength and Young’s modulus and reduce the elongation at break. The thermal conductivity seems more sensitive to the treatments as it decreases for NaOH and silane treatments and increases after benzoylation, permanganate, and thermal treatments. The modification of thermal conductivity may be linked to the modification of the contact resistance between fibers and matrix and the evolution of the thermal properties of the fibers linked to their chemical and structural modifications.

sec.title: Experimental correlation εr, E, and k
sec.p:
Figure 5 represents the relative variation of the Young’s modulus (E/Epolyester – 1) and the relative permittivity (εr/εr, polyester – 1) vs. relative variation of the thermal conductivity. It can be seen that the relative permittivity increases linearly with the thermal conductivity for composites prepared using untreated fibers and also for some treated fibers. Thus, experimental data were fitted using Equation (2): (2) where g corresponds to the Young’s modulus (E) or to the relative permittivity (ε). Figure 5.
Comparison between relative variations of relative permittivity, Young’s modulus, and thermal conductivity of composites.

The values of α and the regression factor are given in Table 5. A similar result was reported by Agoudjil et al.34,41 using ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) matrix filled with two types of spheres sizes of barium titanate. These α values are approximately equal to the ones obtained in this article (Table 5). Besides, the value of the slope obtained for the Young’s modulus (E) is in the same order of magnitude than the ones observed in the comparison between zero-shear viscosity and thermal conductivity.41 (Table 5). This correlation was observed by the authors of Agoudjil et al.34,41 when varying the filler volume fraction. In this work, it seems that the correlation is valid also when using thermal and permanganate treatments. The correlation observed between εr, E, and k is confirmed by the values of the regression factors which are close to one. It must be kept in mind that according to Bigg,42 all three parameters εr, E, and k (and viscosity η as well) of two-phase filled composites can be described by the same type of equations. The conditions of applicability of such an approach are (i) the contribution of each phase is separate and (ii) absence of influence of each phase on the other one, i.e., absence or weak interaction between phases. Evidently the composites with untreated fibers and treated with NaOH have got under these conditions and have similar concentrate dependencies for εr, E, and k. Data given in Table 5 show that the value of α is two times higher for the transport process in the field of mechanical forces (g = E and g = η) than in the dielectric field (g = εr) and does not equal 1. It means that value of α is sensitive to the mechanism of the transport process (or kind of the transport properties) and has minimal value for thermal conductivity. In the case of treated fibers the interaction between phases appears and the developed transition layer between two phases can exist as third phase. Thus, conditions (i) and (ii) are not applicable for treated systems and the correlation vanishes. As a result, a clear correlation exists between the thermal, dielectric and the mechanical properties; the relative variations of these quantities are proportional. This correlation was observed for fillers34,41 and for fibers in this work, thus it would be interesting in future works to check if this phenomenon is a general rule. Table 5.
Values of the parameter α of Equation (2)
Property Composite α + Δα Regression factor R2
g = εr Polyester /sisala 4.857 ± 0.055 0.999
BT9b,c 3.727 ± 0.067 0.996
BT105b,c 4.502 ± 0.070 0.996
g = E Polyester /sisala 8.941 ± 0.315 0.986
g = η* BT9c 8.518 ± 0.213 0.996
BT105c 7.821 ± 0.495 0.968
aValues from this work; bValues from Sreekumar et al.31; cValues from Sreekumar et al.38

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study explored the effect of treated and untreated fibers on the thermophysical, dielectric and mechanical properties of sisal/polyester composites. Addition of the untreated sisal fiber into polyester resin resulted in an increase in thermal conductivity, diffusivity, relative permittivity, tensile strength, Young’s modulus of the composites while a decrease in elongation at break and specific heat. Most of the fiber surface modifications improved the relative permittivity and tensile properties of the composites, but to varying degrees. The opposite effect is noted for the elongation at break. A small increase in the thermal conductivity was observed for the composites reinforced with fiber after permanganate and benzoylation treatments. The use of NaOH and silane treated fibers decreased the thermal conductivity of the composites. However, in terms of efficiency benzoylation seems to be the best treatment regarding mechanical, dielectric and thermophysical properties. As concluded in a recent paper41 on this topic, a linear correlation was observed between relative permittivity, Young’s modulus, and thermal conductivity for untreated, thermal, and permanganate-treated sisal fiber/polyester composites.
